summary: This document is a news digest email from a Senior Intelligence Specialist at the U.S. Attorney's Office, dated February 22, 2019. It compiles numerous news articles covering global terrorism, criminal cases, and geopolitical events, including a brief mention of the ruling on the Jeffrey Epstein prosecution agreement. The email serves as an intelligence update on terrorism-related activities worldwide.

persons.name: Christopher Paul Hasson
persons.context: Lt. Christopher Paul Hasson was ordered to jail without bail, accused of being a domestic terrorist. Federal agents recovered 15 guns and ammunition from his apartment, and he studied extremist manifestos.

persons.name: Jennifer Sykes
persons.context: Prosecutor Jennifer Sykes claimed Hasson used his government computer to search for information on terrorists like the Unabomber and Eric Rudolph.

persons.name: Abdi Yusuf Hassan
persons.context: A U.S. citizen charged in the kidnapping of a journalist in Somalia in 2012. He was arrested in Minneapolis and faces six counts including kidnapping conspiracy.

persons.name: Mohamed Tahlil Mohamed
persons.context: Co-defendant with Abdi Yusuf Hassan in the kidnapping of journalist Michael Scott Moore in Somalia.

persons.name: Michael Scott Moore
persons.context: German-American author who was kidnapped in Somalia in January 2012 and held for nearly three years. He confirmed Mohamed Tahlil Mohamed was one of his captors.

persons.name: Hoda Muthana
persons.context: A US-born woman who left Alabama to join ISIS. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo stated she has no legal basis to return to the United States.

persons.name: Mike Pompeo
persons.context: Announced that Hoda Muthana would not be welcomed back to the US, stating she had no valid passport or visa.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Signed the National Strategy to Combat Terrorist Travel, calling for increased biometric technologies and data sharing. Also warned Venezuelan military officials to abandon President Maduro.

persons.name: Bryant Villas
persons.context: American who joined al-Qaeda in Afghanistan, was captured, and later provided key information to the FBI about terrorist identities and operations.

persons.name: Andrew McCabe
persons.context: Termed the information provided by Bryant Villas as 'incredibly valuable'.

persons.name: Kevin Omar Mohamed
persons.context: Canadian who traveled to Syria to join an al-Qaeda faction, pleaded guilty, and was released from prison despite being deemed a 'high risk to public safety'.

persons.name: Fabien Clain
persons.context: Known as the 'Voice of Paris Attacks', reported killed in an airstrike in Baghuz, Syria, the last pocket held by IS.

persons.name: Hatib Hajan Sawadjaan
persons.context: Reported to be the 'acting emir' of ISIS in the Philippines, suspected of masterminding deadly bombings including a January 2019 cathedral attack.

persons.name: Hugo Carvajal
persons.context: Turned against President Nicolas Maduro, accusing him and his inner circle of corruption, drug trafficking, and ties to Hezbollah. He urged the military to break with Maduro.

persons.name: Nicolas Maduro
persons.context: Accused by Hugo Carvajal of leading a corrupt government involved in drug trafficking and blocking humanitarian aid. Facing pressure from the opposition and the US.

persons.name: Juan Guaido
persons.context: Claims the presidency of Venezuela and is attempting to push humanitarian aid into the country against Maduro's wishes.

persons.name: Nestor Reverol
persons.context: Named by Hugo Carvajal as part of Maduro's corrupt inner circle involved in drug trafficking.

persons.name: Tareck El Aissami
persons.context: Named by Hugo Carvajal as part of Maduro's corrupt inner circle involved in drug trafficking.

persons.name: Ahmed Omar Abu Ali
persons.context: Charged in 2005 with plotting to assassinate President Bush in conspiracy with Al Qaeda members in Saudi Arabia. He was allegedly tortured in Saudi custody.

persons.name: Ashraf Nubani
persons.context: Attorney for Ahmed Omar Abu Ali, claimed his client was whipped and handcuffed while in Saudi custody.

persons.name: Liam O'Grady
persons.context: Presided over the initial court appearance of Ahmed Omar Abu Ali, assuring his attorney he would not be mistreated in US custody.

persons.name: John Greenagel
persons.context: Recruited by the CIA to befriend Soviet KGB officer Yuri Pavlov in San Francisco in the 1970s, providing insights to his CIA handler.

persons.name: Yuri Pavlov
persons.context: Undercover KGB officer based at the Soviet Consulate in San Francisco, targeted by the CIA through access agent John Greenagel.

connections.description: Listed as co-defendants in the kidnapping conspiracy of journalist Michael Scott Moore in Somalia.
Hassan is accused of participating in the kidnapping of journalist Michael Scott Moore.
Michael Scott Moore confirmed that Mohamed Tahlil Mohamed was one of his captors.
Villas provided information to the FBI, which former acting director Andrew McCabe termed 'incredibly valuable'.
Carvajal, a former intelligence chief and congressman, publicly turned against President Maduro, accusing him of corruption and dictatorship.
Carvajal accused Reverol, the interior minister, of being part of Maduro's corrupt inner circle involved in drug trafficking.
Carvajal accused El Aissami, a minister and former vice president, of being part of Maduro's corrupt inner circle involved in drug trafficking.
Ashraf Nubani served as defense attorney for Ahmed Omar Abu Ali during his court appearance.
Greenagel, a CIA access agent, cultivated a friendship with KGB officer Yuri Pavlov to provide psychological insights to the CIA.

events.title: Coast Guard Officer Ordered to Jail
events.description: Lt. Christopher Paul Hasson ordered to remain in jail without bail, accused of being a domestic terrorist after federal agents recovered 15 guns and ammunition from his apartment.

events.title: Kidnapping of Journalist in Somalia
events.description: Journalist Michael Scott Moore was abducted by heavily armed captors in Galkayo, Somalia, and held for nearly three years over a $20 million ransom demand.

events.title: State Department Denies Return of ISIS Bride
events.description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced that Hoda Muthana, a US-born woman who joined ISIS, would not be allowed to return to the United States, citing no legal basis.

events.title: Trump Signs Anti-Terror Travel Strategy
events.description: President Donald Trump signed the National Strategy to Combat Terrorist Travel, calling for increased use of biometric technologies and data sharing.

events.title: Venezuelan Official Defects
events.description: Hugo Carvajal, former Venezuelan intelligence chief and current congressman, publicly broke with President Nicolas Maduro, accusing him of corruption and drug trafficking, and urged the military to allow humanitarian aid.

events.title: Man Charged in Plot to Kill President Bush
events.description: Ahmed Omar Abu Ali was charged with conspiring with Al Qaeda members in Saudi Arabia to assassinate President George W. Bush, either by shooting or car bomb.

events.title: Judge Rules on Epstein Prosecution Agreement
events.description: A judge ruled that prosecutors broke the law in the non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein (mentioned in a linked article summary within the digest).

keyFacts: A U.S. Coast Guard officer, Lt. Christopher Paul Hasson, was jailed as an alleged domestic terrorist after authorities found 15 guns and over 1,000 rounds of ammunition in his home.
U.S. citizen Abdi Yusuf Hassan was charged in New York for his role in the 2012 kidnapping of journalist Michael Scott Moore in Somalia, who was held for nearly three years.
Hugo Carvajal, Venezuela's former intelligence chief, defected from the Maduro regime, publicly accusing the president and his inner circle of corruption, drug trafficking, and ties to Hezbollah.
The email digest references a ruling that prosecutors broke the law in the non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein, though details are not provided in the text.
The document includes a historical case from 2005 where Ahmed Omar Abu Ali was charged with plotting to assassinate President George W. Bush in conspiracy with Al Qaeda.
